author: Hugh Morris
title: Price more important than punctuality for flying Britons
text: Travel comparison site Momondo asked 1,000 people their priorities when selecting an airline with which to travel, and 56 per cent said cost of the flights was the most important factor to take into consideration, with 44 per cent saying a precise departure time was of most importance. A third of respondents said direct flights, with no stopovers, was top priority when booking flights, while a fifth said it was dependant on the location of the airport and its proximity to their home or hotel. The survey’s results suggest that British holidaymakers are a fickle bunch, with 5 per cent choosing an airline based on collecting frequent flier points, and 13 per cent selecting a carrier based on familiarity and trust. Momondo also quizzed travellers on their preferences for on-flight facilities. As incidents of "legroom wars" have become more common in the last year , coupled with the fact that most plane seats are shrinking, it is no surprise perhaps that passengers identified seating as their biggest priority when booking a flight. Thirty-nine per cent said that comfortable seating with ample leg room was their main concern. This man could make use of the empty seat in front of him - if the plane had these new smart seats installed Photo: Fotolia/AP • Legroom wars: the seat to change it all With more than half the respondents governed by cost when selecting their flights however, more than a quarter of Britons (27 per cent) don’t give facilities any thought when booking. The respondents were also not particularly fussed when it came to the nature of the cabin crew, with just 8 per cent saying that service mattered to them. Just 5 per cent said on-board Wi-Fi was a relevant issue, and only 7 per cent said that in-flight entertainment was a priority. Lassa Skole Hansen, from Momondo, said: “We understand Brits love a bargain when it comes to travel. With the number of airlines today competing for sales on the same routes, many travellers are happy to search for bargains to secure the seats they want. “It’s clear though that in-flight comfort is most important to Britons still. Whilst travellers are happy to forego the free gin and tonic or beer, available on more upmarket carriers mid-air, many are booking smarter – opting ahead of time for a mid-range airline at a better price, which offers a modicum of comfort.” Telegraphtravel
